You shouldn't shoot at patrols. They cause more enemies to spawn if you don't eliminate the enemies quickly enough. Stealth is best for this mission type. When pressing a silo button there should be no guards (you can stealth kill them) or patrols (you can wait for them to leave) near you. Pressing the button will cause many enemies to spawn near you and attack the silo. You can distract them with smokes or sentries. If you fail to defend a silo and there are enemies present, you shouldn't press the button again. Instead you should kill them or move stealthily to a safer silo to retry. Eventually the enemies at the one you failed will move away like regular patrols.   Stealth is best for this mission. So much so that I have an easier time doing it solo compared to with a team who will impulsively shoot at everything they see.

You are playing difficulty 8 - impossible‚Ä¶. Sooo impossibly hard as advertised.
It's difficulty 8 for a reason. And just like you said (and another one of your teammates also said), you didn't even know what the silo mission was about. You can't honestly expect to be able to hot drop into an already chaotic difficulty 8 mission not knowing what to do and expect to clear it easily. The absurd amount of bile titans is a symptom of that fact. This mission wasn't designed for you to endlessly defeat all the breach spawns for eternity (which seemed to be what your team was doing). That's one of the points of diff8 and 9 missions, that you don't take every fight cause you simply (by design) don't have enough means to sustain that long and you eventually get overrun. It just so happens in this mission that you have to defend a certain area for a definite amount of time (if you plan the engage correctly, ie you clear out the silo area before activating it, and assign teammates to guard each entrance/choke instead of everyone running around in the chaos).   Could the game use a little nerf with the amount of bile spawns? It's definitely arguably healthier for the community, of which a large majority aren't sweaty gamers min-maxxing every loadout and approach to each mission. But even as a casual player, you surely can't reasonably expect to hotdrop to a mission fully blind to the objective and expect the game balance to cater to you instead of other way around. It's the player that needs to adjust to the current state. If you can't handle diff8 in this patch, then play diff7 or something else. The devs will see the numbers and will patch accordingly to what they intend for the difficulty to be. If diff9 was intended to only be completed by the sweatiest of the sweats, then so be it, if that's the goal of the devs. But you cant be complaining you can't do diff8 if you don't know the mission obj. I'm sure with mechanics like yours, you def could do diff8 if you know how the mission was supposed to be played, instead of just running around killing everything you saw.

My problem with this is it's honestly difficult to really know how much of this was the result of the "balancing" in the patch, and how much was the studio being clever with social media.  The Dev team was very open about the fact that they have a team that spends their time monitoring play who will alter fate (spawn in stratagems, a nest, etc), and they know the player ID's of the people with the biggest followings/most viewed HD2 content.   There have been way too many cases of insane stuff happening to streamers / YouTubers that the rest of us plebs seem to never experience, at least not to these extremes, and when you look at these clips of gameplay keeping in mind that the studio clearly stated that they alter team & individual gameplay in real-time to add something "unique", so I now assume that a good portion of the crazier video/clips that go viral did so at least in part because the studio is playing god a bit with the most popular players to create more viral moments, keep the buzz high and along with the buzz is continued huge sales revenues.  We've had cases of Dev teams playing God before, usually to be @ssholes, to catch/punish cheats or attempting to prove a point, and I'm sure many other studios do it and we never really notice, but this is different, and while I love this game and the breath of fresh air it has brought to the industry, I fear that this is going to become standard operating procedure for all multi-player games once the other studios realize the power of fabricating viral moments now that the player community apparently doesn't seem to mind.  It will become abused, and I already feel like I can't trust some of the footage we see uploaded as a genuine typical player experience.

last night i cleared this mission on my first try with only 1 random on difficulty 9, its about understanding the nuances of the mission more than defeating the bugs. i did not feel like we were sweating it so i think its just about knowledge that we learned on that mission.  1. if the silo is lost, wait until the breaches clear COMPLETELY to reactivate it. a new wave spawns every time you hit the button. communication helps here, if a teammate doesnt know this then they might keep pressing it   2. Silos take friendly fire, A LOT of friendly fire happens with explosive strategems like cluster bombs or air strikes, dont use these. the high spread guns also cause a lot of damage to the silos, especially when the chaff enemies swarm the building, so at least fire from the side if using these.  3. ironically, bile titans and chargers arent the worst enemy type here, the Hunters instant agro on the silo and attempt to take it out as soon as they approach it, so the chaff ends up doing more damage to the Silo Shield and Silo Health than the larger enemies. controlling the amount of small enemies is usually more important it seems.  4. you have 40 minutes, you can take your time.  all this said, the spawns for heavies is WAY too high right now, especially on bugs.

PSA: Termicide Silos work similarly to geographic survey objectives. That is to say, activating a silo triggers a bug breach. Activating a new Silo triggers a bug breach, reactivating the same silo after it failed triggers a bug breach. There's no cap to how many bug breaches you can trigger and it WILL trigger whenever you activate a Silo every single time.  Pace yourselves and clear out any big bugs before you make another attempt on the silo, otherwise all you're doing is spawning more and more BTs until you've passed the point of no return and have made the mission nigh impossible to finish cleanly.

We lose about half the campaigns (mostly to timeout) and just because of this mission we had to drop down to diff 6, other missions are fine to complete. Call it a skill issue, but things clearly aren't working as intended.  Now for some tips. -Silos are affected by friendly fire; guns, strats, turrets, explosions, everything does damage to it.   -Despite Bile Titans not attacking the silo (titans and chargers aggro players) their steps will absolutely destroy the silo, so don't try to kite them around it if it's activating (same with making chargers hit the silo while charging). Lead them away if possible before dispatching them, especially if using a stratagem.  -Turrets are great, but can absolutely wreck the silo, so regular mortars are a no go, however the Tesla is a hidden gem because only chargers and titans will aggro it while the silo is activating, All other bugs will ignore it as they walk towards the silo, basically giving you an entire lane you don't have to worry about unless it's destroyed. -The laser, while great at killing chargers and smaller bugs, will go over the silo while activated and do massive damage. So I can't recommend it. -Orbital stun strike, while unconventional it has a very short cooldown and locks down a large area preventing all bugs from moving (except bile titans) sometimes this buys your team extra time to deal with the titans and chargers, while also keeping swathes of bugs still for a nicely placed stratagem. It can also be thrown at the silo as an emergency to stop the bugs from breaking it while you are so close to completing it. This also applies for the stun mortar (I am not sure if their impacts do damage to the silo, but I doubt it). -While I have not tested it myself, smokes can possibly prevent the silo from being damaged if they are placed at its base.  Possible bug, but silos can take damage while offline (usually heralded by the loud alarm noise) you can notice that when you start it that it can start damaged, even in critical state, almost guaranteeing that you won't be able to complete the activation. This is seen at 1:06 and 4:58 in the video. This game is starting to disappoint me more and more. The core gameplay is good as it was in the beginning, the story is good, everything surrounding the game is good, except for the balance and playing higher difficulties. Yes not everyone should be able to beat the highest difficulty that‚Äôs not my problem, my problem is with how they chose to make the game hard: Spam heavy‚Äôs and turn the game into a running simulator. There is such a thing as a fun challenge, helldivers is currently failing miserably to provide that. Pressing the stim key should heal your character, pretty simple concept seen before in many games. Instead pressing the stim key in this game sends a prayer to the god of health, and 1/5 times you will be rewarded with health. On top of that, stim invulnerability is incredibly inconsistent, half the time you can rank three hulks shooting you at the same time while stimmed, the other half of the time you get shot by a regular MG raided and lose all hp. Then you have the fact that when you get shot your camera gets shaken so incredibly hard it‚Äôs impossible to hit anything for a solid few seconds, yea sure it‚Äôs immersive and realistic but how is that fun and how is that skill based? Then you have bile spewers and hulk scorchers with their incredibly inconsistent damage, sometimes they hit you dead on and it slowly starts burning you, other times they barely touch you with the edge of the flame/bile and HP goes from 100 to 0.  The common argument for why all this exists is because the current balance philosophy revolves entirely around the existence of stratagems, which allow you to prevent enemies from getting close where all this bullshit happens. This is just a terrible argument, this is supposed to be a horde shooter no? Maybe make it so that shooting your guns is actually a fun and viable playstyle. Rather the game on higher difficulties basically becomes stratagem hero with the added bonus of being a running simulator, where you have to constantly run from objective to objective throwing stratagems and not shooting your gun at all cause it‚Äôs useless.  An easy way to fix this is to simply make it easier to survive, and decrease the amount of reinforcements. Either make the guns better and more fun to use, or fix stims so that you can use them whenever and getting shot doesn‚Äôt cancel them. Whatever they have to do, make it easier to survive but give us less reinforcements, cause right now the game is not fun at all on anything higher than 6

The devs need to consider more than just 'add more massive bugs' when they're planning the distribution of bug types during missions. They need to consider how an actual hive would work. What are chargers for? I would assume defense. What are bile titans for? Unlike chargers, I would say digging hive tunnels with their acid; same as the other spitter types. So would a hive of huge size even have a need for that many bile titans? Most likely not... and so there wouldn't BE that many. Only enough to keep expanding the hive in small areas. That many bile titans would require so much food and other resources just to keep alive that they would strip the hive of food for the other bugs, and so wouldn't exist in those numbers.  At the same time... isn't this kind of chaos and over the top stuff what people playing those levels are looking for? I've seen posts where people were claiming they wanted that kind of insanity, only easier so they don't die so often... and that seems counter intuitive. Either you want the insanity, or you play a level lower down so it's a little less insane. Yes, all levels should be playable, and if I were a high end player, I would challenge the devs to play their own game and show everyone how it could work; they'd learn the hard way and be able to make adjustments. But if anything, I feel like the main thing that needs balancing is damage. If they sent that many bile titans and you could effectively kill them as long as you had the skill, it wouldn't be quite so ridiculous. Yet for some reason, the weapons are being kept to a surprisingly weak level of damage, and are whole universes of inaccurate, while the enemies are absolute nightmare bullet sponges. I think the problem with the new way that they have enemies spawn doesnt actually do what they think it does to reduce spawn rates.   So we've got more of the little guys in a mission right? We're supposed to have reduced charger and BT spawn rates as a result. Problem is is that all of the little guys, save for the Nursing and Bile Spewers, seem to be capable of calling in reinforcements. The little guys can call up to chargers in size from what I've seen, and the warrior on up size can call in something as large as a bile titan. If a hive commander calls in reinforcements (along with its normal warrior entourage that it calls in on aggro) its the most likely to summon a bile titan, and in my own experience does nearly every single time.   So now the problem is that we've got more of the little guys, especially hunters, who make it difficult to control everything. I find myself running away from massive hordes of hunters to avoid being overwhelmed , which makes CCing a swarm extremely difficult. Warriors, Guards, and Commanders all spawn in greater numbers too which increases the odds of one of them calling for backup. This eventually cycles into the same problem that we had before, but now its just come about in a different fashion.   I think the only way to actually solve this would be to have a hard limit on the number of large armored enemies that could be on the field at any one time. Using a point-based system could work; similar to what games like Risk of Rain 2 do. BTs are worth like, 5 points. Chargers 2, etc. Then there can only be like, 15 points worth of heavy armor on the field at any given time and there's a set time between when the max point value drops from 15 before the director can call in any more heavy armor. That kind of thing could help with the seemingly endless stream of chargers and BTs and let the players catch up even in the most dire of situations. __________________________________________________________________________  With this particular mission I think enemy spawning works a little differently. While I have seen the little guys that wander around at the start try to call in reinforcements I cant say that I've seen any of them call in bug breaches mid wave. I'm also fairly convinced that pressing the silo button triggers 3 bug breaches to open every time and that there will always be 3 bile titans to start. This mission type is likely coded to keep spawning things until the silo either stops or reaches 100%, and those spawns dont seem to be affected by the recent changes to spawn rates.   Again, the above point system that I mentioned, along with the aforementioned cooldown could help solve the heavy armored bug issue, because that kind of craziness is only containable with something like the emp mortars, and I'd really like to be able to play 9 with randos and not have to be super extra meta sweaty to complete it.   IMO theres nothing wrong with giving your playerbase the ability to solo your highest difficulty and that's not something that the devs should discourage.  Edit:  Another thought I had:   Come to think of it, this might also be what causes the same issue to happen with bots on the civilian defense missions during planetary defenses. I betcha that both this and that mission use a different spawning system to what we typically find in a "normal" 40 minute mission.  It could be that the way that the enemies are currently coded isnt conducive to wave based defense missions, even if they do go off of the new spawn system. It feels like making it a wave based spawn system is just emulating the worst possible scenario for both races, and we all know that fighting both of them in other missions relies on being able to break line of sight and reengage when things get too hot.   The enemy structure and AI is just not designed for wave based spawning, and by having it do so in these two mission types completely bypasses any safety checks that would normally be in place to keep things from getting this nutty.

Helldivers 2 seems to be confused on what a recoilless rifle is... The termicide missions are kind of a unique case right now. The towers spawn breaches EVERY TIME you activate one and every time you reactivate one after it gets destabilized. Its creating a feedback loop where you activating the tower spawning a breach, bugs destabilize the tower, you reactivate and spawn another breach adding more bugs to the party, destabilize even faster, etc. etc. until you run out of reinforcement. It's kinda shitty mission design, tbh. There should be some cooldown before activating the same tower can spawn another breach.  The trick as far as I can tell is to treat each tower activation as it's own thing. Activate it, defend it, if it destabilizes clear the whole breach and reset before trying again.

All the replies saying "this is clearly you and your team's fault for spamming the silo button and spawning in so many waves" need to consider that if this mechanic is so confusing to so many players, maybe it's badly implemented. For every other point-defense objective in the game, once you start the enemy spawns, they don't stop until the objective is done. Rescue missions have also conditioned players to spam objective buttons as soon as possible because getting objectives done quickly is so important. You can't exactly blame players doing this mission type for the first time just assuming that once the spawns start, they don't stop until the objective is complete, and if the objective is interrupted it makes intuitive sense that you should restart it as soon as possible to make up for that lost time. This leads to a failure spiral of pressing the button which spawns more waves which are more likely to interrupt the silo, and due to how every other mission type in the game works, players are more likely to assume that the horde became overwhelming simply because they took too long on the objective rather than associating it with how many times the button got pressed. I don't need a big tutorial pop-up in bold letters saying "DO NOT HIT THE BUTTON" but it would have gone a long way if there was at least a message over the comms saying something like "Listen up, Helldiver, any time these silos start the tremors it makes rile the bugs up like nothing else" which would at least hint at there being an association between new bug spawns and starting the silo.
When the silos are activated, waves of enemies are automatically called. Starting the next silo instantly spawns a new wave. Your team needed to give some time between silo attempts

Lowering the spawn rates of only the biggest while increasing everything else, just results in an overall increase to the spawn rates of everything, including the biggest enemies. Because the little and medium guys are so much more numerous, they can call in reinforcements more often. Because they call in reinforcements more often, the number of bigger enemies, which often come with the reinforcements, has become more numerous. So the reduction in bigger enemies is pointless, because they increased the number of smaller units that spawn them in. They effectively only increased the spawn rates of everything.

I believe it isn't skill issue, but a communication one. Every time you activate sub or main objectives, it spawns enemies (bug breaches and automaton ships) and each spawn, in different types of missions, have different scripts for what types and how many enemies. Letting your team know what the objective is about and when you'll activate it can save some trouble. The game isn't balanced, not because of the spawn rate or number of enemies, but because of the glitches and matchmaking, where one mistake can cost lives (yours and of your teammates) and the objective itself. One way to fix this is matchmaking people with similar completed missions in the same difficulty, and trying to pair players with high kills/death and others with low kills/death. Communication is still key in coop plays. So instead of criticizing and pointing fingers, how about everyone complaining just start communicating, as no one really needs to be a pro and know everything they're doing? It's supposed to be fun, according to the devs themselves, so those that know more help those that know less about the game.

I see a huge disparity in people's opinions about spawn rates and difficulties and I really do think that the people who are running around kiting half a dozen titans at any given moment are bringing it on themselves and not doing the things they could be doing to avoid those situations.  I'm not going to deny the game has it's flaws which I hope get solved but I don't think difficulty or spawn rates are one of those issues. I am of the opinion that the hardest difficulties SHOULD be near impossible for teams that aren't making the right choices and are causing endless hordes to spawn way faster than they can kill them. If you make the hardest difficulties do-able for those teams then the teams that ARE being smart and ARE playing cohesively are just going to breeze through it, and that's no fun either. It makes more sense to me for teams that are struggling to instead lower the difficulty to a manageable level to suit their team and how they're playing rather than expecting the whole game to be lowered to their standard and in the process making the game too easy for the people who are already clearing the current highest difficulties consistently. If you want to play the highest difficulties, be my guest and I hope the liberation goes well, but I don't see why people should expect to beat it by just going in with a bunch of random teammates without much communication or cohesion and be able to beat it consistently.

So 3 issues I noticed with this particular video, the unfamiliarity with the mission type lead to poor choices made when specing your loadout (not your fault here we are all new to a mission at one point), but this leads to the second point the loadouts. For this mission type I've found a sentry heavy loadout is best in particular the teslas, as there are choke points around the towers placing the tesla in said locations effectively locks them down from most enemies, along with a autocannon for support placed a bit further back, we ran with a recoilless/EAT for heavy targets the sentries couldn't deal with and had a 2/2 split between the regular mortar and ems mortar among the squad for dealing with most bug clusters at range. And last restarting the silos every time they go down before you manage to clear everything out is a solid way to get overwhelmed, as it appears the starting them ramps up the spawn rate considerably, which from what I was able to tell seemed to be occurring in your particular game and thus leading to the insanity we witnessed in the video.  That said tho the game does still feel a bit... "off" when it comes to the spawns outside that mission type, I can't quite put my finger on what it is, but it does feel like its goes from 0 to 11 really quick at the drop of a hat in many cases. That said I wouldn't mind the heavy spawn rate if we had the tools available to deal with them adequately and since the devs want us to depend on the strategems, I personally think that off feeling comes from the long cooldown time of several strategems in particular the orbitals, which leads you to kiteing more often than not which is not particularly fun gameplay in most circumstances. Now I can understand the long cooldown period of say backpack items, heavy weapons and sentries as they are present on the field for quite some time and have far less chance of getting foiled by a enemy just moving a few feet away from the targeted area before the long cooldown hits as in the case of many orbitals, so maybe tweaking that cooldown rate would have a positive effect and allow us to depend on our strategems a bit more without having to delve into kiteing as much.  And to get ahead of somebody saying "oh you want this game to be easy mode" or something to that effect, no I rather enjoy the pucker factor when things go sideways, but at the same time I would like more plausible options to reverse the situation as well that are not wholly dependent on just waiting out a timer.

To me, Difficulty 7 is the magic baseline the game should be balanced around for your averaged experienced player, given it's the lowest difficulty where Super Samples are available. Difficulty 7 should be manageable for pick up groups, without mics, who are LvL 25+, and who understand the game's mechanics. It should require bringing some sort of AT weaponry, but not require every single person to be speced for killing tanks, and perfectly space out their cooldowns. It should have chaotic engagements, but still allow for some time between engagements, and the opportunity for stealth.   At launch, this did feel like the sweet spot for me, as the above is how I generally play. I'm okay with struggling with Difficulty 8 and 9, as that's half on me for not having a coordinated group. Currently, Difficulty 5 and 6 feels closer to what 7 felt like at launch. I've just bumped my difficulty down now, as I only need 8 more Super Samples before everything's matched, but I could see how frustrating this all must be for people starting their Super Sample grind.

TL;DR K1 and A4 spammed Silo 03's activation a lot, spawning in way too many Titans to deal with at once. Each Silo activation can spawn (in my experience) up to 3 Titans, so it's really not a button that should be spammed.  A more detailed analysis of this mission as a whole:  1. It's a Termicide mission, meaning you have to activate the central tower once (which was already done when you landed), then activate and defend the three battery silos. The silos are like the geothermal objectives -- they will spawn (in my experience) 2-3 breaches every time they are activated. However, the silos have limited health (and are damaged by friendly fire!), if they take too much damage they will reset.  2. You dropped in at around T-33:00, meaning your team had played for 7 minutes roughly by the time you showed up, and had already thrown an SOS beacon. You also had 14 reinforcements left at that time, so your teammates had died 6 times by then.  3. K1 (host) activates Silo 02 about 5 seconds after you drop in, and it's immediately at the critically unstable (taken lots of damage) phase. Not completely sure why that is -- there IS a charger on the other side of it (1:07) that may have dealt some damage, or perhaps a stray rocket or bullet spray damaged it as it activated. I believe this Silo activation is responsible for titans #1, #2, #3, and #4. Your team kills 3 titans in relatively short order, and the Silo is successfully activated. This will be the only Silo activation that goes well.  4. Hunters are really annoying now, I agree.  5. Titan #5 seems to be a patrolling Titan, as I didn't see a breach that spawned it. It's teamed up with Titan #4 (or #3?), one of the Titans spawned by Silo 02's activation.  6. (3:27) Presumably at about T-30:00, somebody (I think either K1 or A4) activates Silo 01. This will spawn Titans #7 and #8. #4 is still prowling the map, and I believe #6 appears from a patrol as well. Despite all this, the team does manage to (barely) defend Silo 01. It's been about 4 and a half minutes, and you've completed 2/3 main headaches. There are now 4 titans roaming the map, but as long as nobody activates Silo 03 you should be able to handle it.  7. (4:23) Titan #9 appears out of thin air. Again, I'm assuming that it's meant to be part of an enemy patrol. This is the fourth patrolling Titan I think, which wouldn't be too bad if they weren't teaming up with all of the ones spawned in from the rapid Silo activations.  8. (4:57) At about T-27:30, somebody (again either K1 or A4) activates Silo 03. Keep in mind that Titans #6? and #9 are still on the map and approaching the team. This activation will spawn Titan #10. To my knowledge, all three remaining Titans are wiped out before the next activation.  9. (6:10) At about T-26:00, somebody (I think it's A4 this time) activates Silo 03 again. This spawns in Titans #11 and #12, and the incoming meteor storm makes short work of the Silo (and you).  10. Titan #13 seems to have spawned in from a bug breach of some sort -- either a regular breach or by another activation from K1. If it is an activation, the fact that an orbital laser is targetting Silo 03 means that it failed immediately. Hey, free Bile Titan :D  11. (7:40) At about T-23:00 (judging from how the bar is half completed), A4 has again activated Silo 03, which spawns in Titan #14. After taking it out, the team is "out of ammo, stratagems on cooldown, etc.", and your team shows a surprising amount of restraint by waiting until everyone is reinforced and resupplied before activating Silo 03 again.  12. What's the point of these heavy hitter stratagems if they don't actually kill the targets on a properly aimed bomb drop.   Secondly the way the enemy spawns work on these defense objectives (this applies to ALL missions with an objective that auto aggros enemies to your location as well as both factions). The game doesn't bother telling you this but as soon as you push a button to start the silo it will instantly start a bug breach. There is no clear indication in game that this is how these objectives work other than the breach actually occurring as soon as the objective is started. This is a massive problem if you're with a bunch of randoms who don't know this and are spamming the objectives before you finish clearing out the last wave from a bug breach. The game doesn't tell you you CAN wait before starting/restarting the objectives to finish off the bugs from the last wave.   There is unfortunately not much that can be done about the stratagems being inconsistent and wonky other than to wait for the devs to buff and tweak the aoe and damage. The objectives however should have a massive warning that asks you "Are you ready to start this objective? Starting this objective will immediately spawn/aggro a wave of enemies be prepared."   Just tell the player that  1. Starting the objective will immediately spawn a bug breach and waves of enemies  2. That if you need to restart an objective or start a new objective you can wait to clear the bugs so there isn't like 6 bile titans on the field at once.

You guys this isn't a hang out mission. You have to quickly complete the objective and get out.
What's the issue? Lot's of titans, lot's of enemies. It's meant to be hard 8/9 difficulty. A note about your comment at 12:16 "Do we really expect people to play like sweats in public games?" Yes. If you're playing at almost the highest difficulty the game has to offer, YES it's meant to be challenge to overcome. I feel like a lot of people are just making video's about that almost max difficulty is too hard and they need balancing patches to fix it, while on the other hand vouching for casual play and public game lobbies without communication.  These missions in particular are new and misunderstood. The game spawns enemies based on players around it and activities. With activities I refer to objective interactive things like terminals, ICBM steps, Geological surveys and the Gas batteries in this mission. Everytime you restart one of these machines it spawns a new wave of monsters (at difficulty 7 or higher bile titans are almost guaranteed). If you fail to wipe the wave in time, the battery dies and you have to restart, if you or a teammate immediately restarts the battery it start another activity and spawns another wave, compounding the spawnrate of enemies and making it EVEN harder to get the objective completed this time.  Some tips for these missions: If you fail to finish an activity clear space or take distance from the objective before starting again to give you and your time to regroup, clear chaff and re-arm. If you insist on bringing a mech the pelican dropping it off can be a useful tool in fighting, it's autocannon shreds heavies. For max effect, use it in line of sight of bile titan (Without getting it puked on ofc) Turrets are incredibly strong because of the static nature of these objectives, if you can keep the chaff at bay the autogun- and rocket turret are valuable asset in countering titans. The EAT-17 is often a better pick for "Static" fights, since you can stockpile the launchers faster than with the recoiless. Your team can grab them when needed for a quick charger or titan kill, the quicker a titan is dead, the quicker you can move on.  I agree the game needs tweaks and bugfixes, and the devs are hard at work making the game better and bigger all the time. I just don't think that balancing the harder difficulties for casual pub non communicative play is a very relevant issue right now. There are a lot of weird things happening like hellpod steering, ragdoll jank and animations that make playing (Especially when sweating) frustrating. It'd rather have the devs working on removing jank and unpredictability, once they do that we can truly see how higher difficulties play

Even against chargers, it takes like 3-5 impacts from a charger rush to be destroyed. I think the issue people have, is they don't realize mechs are bugged horribly right now. If you turn quickly and fire rockets with mechs, there is an extremely high chance, the rockets will hit your mech and cause you instantly die. This is what's causing people to think their mechs are just spontaneously combusting from a couple of hits.   I mean, any explosion really kills your mech, but against normal hits, lazers, tackles, etc. Your mech can survive quite the beating. It's also good to summon your mech at the start. Mechs have 2 charges per mission with a fairly long CD. I think like 8 minutes? So if you use it in the middle or toward the end, it's basically like you're not using one of your selected strategems.   Anyways, in my personal opinion, the spawns are not as bad as you think. My advice is load out depending on the mission. Missions where you know you're going to get a fuck ton of small waves, just use the machine gun/stalwart. Contrary to popular belief, those guns are extremely good at mass murder, even against moderately armored units, you'll mow them down.   If you're worried about biles, spear launcher and recoilless rifle are extremely good. 1-2 spear launcher shots will kill a bile. Recoilless, can 1-2 shot as well if you place the shot well. The problem is reload but it's not too bad.   Also the orbital railcannon strike will almost always one shot a bile titan. You can use it every 3 minutes. It's far better then the 500 KG bomb if your goal is to kill big shit.

PSA: Termicide Silos work similarly to geographic survey objectives. That is to say, activating a silo triggers a bug breach. Activating a new Silo triggers a bug breach, reactivating the same silo after it failed triggers a bug breach. There's no cap to how many bug breaches you can trigger and it WILL trigger whenever you activate a Silo every single time.  Pace yourselves and clear out any big bugs before you make another attempt on the silo, otherwise all you're doing is spawning more and more BTs until you've passed the point of no return and have made the mission nigh impossible to finish cleanly.
